I can't believe I'm wasting my first review on this show...
Ousama Game The Animation (King's Game in English) is a perfect example of how you can have good ideas and still write a terrible story. Honestly, that's the only way I can even recommend this show: if you want a case study in how to ruin a story, I can't think of a better example than this. I can't in good conscience advise watching King's Game for any other reason. It is a train-wreck from beginning to end, and only two things kept me watching until the end: it was admittedly really fun to joinin on the episode discussions every week and talk about why this show is so bad, and I felt a morbid curiosity to see just how bad it could get and where the flaming wreckage would land. There were times when this show made me seriously question if I was suffering from some uncharacteristic streak of masochism...


Let me start with the good things:

The OP and ED songs are actually pretty good, it's a shame they had to be attached to this show. And there are some times when the show can actually be funny. It's not supposed to be funny at all, but the straight-faced absurdity of some parts is just too much to take remotely serious. Finally, there are times when you can see the spark of what could have been a really good idea, but...


And now the bad:

...That spark is, without fail, snuffed out, stomped into the dirt, and urinated on for good measure. And most of the time, it's because every single character in the show is either killed off without even being properly introduced, or so painfully devoid of any logical thought or consistency of character that it is impossible to care about them at all. The characters are easily the worst part of the show, and they consistently drag every other aspect of storytelling into the dirt with them. Personalities do a 180 turn at the drop of a hat, everyone is either unreasonably cruel or hopelessly pathetic, and characters constantly make choices so poor you have to wonder how they've managed to even survive long enough to be part of the game at all. But fear not, poor writing ensures that even in the rare instances that characters aren't being insufferably idiotic, the story still continues to fail at being any sort of horror or thriller and at best an uncompelling mystery with no payoff for the solution (so bad, in-fact, that even after the King's identity is explicitly revealed, some viewers still don't realize that there's nothing more to it, we really do have the complete, albeit absurd, answer; and I can't blame them for not getting it, because it doesn't actually make any sense or explain anything).


To summarize: King's Game is terrible, the characters are quite possibly the worst characters I've ever seen, and it completely fails at everything it has attempted to be and is instead closer to an unintentional comedy. And it's not even worth watching for that, because it's really not that funny very often. It only gets a 2 instead of a 1 because there were at least some good ideas underlying the show, which unfortunately could not reach even a fraction of their potential because of everything that was wrong with the show. I could bash the show for hours, but honestly it's wasted too much of my time already. Don't be like me, don't waste your time on King's Game.

I'm going to get straight to the point, this anime is a dumpster fire. At the best of times it's hilariously nonsensical and at the worst of times, it genuinely hurts to watch.
Story 1/10:
The basic premise of King's Game is... sketchy at best. It just screams edge the more you read it. Honestly, after watching all 12 episodes, I can safely say that an edgy cringe fest would be 1000x better than what we got. There are plot and logic holes so large I am convinced it took actual effort to come up with them. I can't give specific examples because spoilers but let's justsay that this anime actively spits in the face of science on multiple occasions and burns the book on a coherent plot within the first episode. The problem here is it goes so far into the supernatural while still trying to give some scientific and technological explanation. This isn't inherently awful but when you don't have a clue what you're talking about it definitely shows. Besides that, there's just so much that happens that doesn't make sense and the plot takes so many ridiculous twists that it loses itself. It also doesn't help that the first half of the show is just flashback to a different instance of the King's Game which doesn't sound all too bad until you remember that they literally tell you the outcome of each event before it happens. No joke, the first half of this anime is them telling you a thing happened and then showing you said thing. Except any and all enjoyment that could come out of these flashbacks is the tension of not knowing what's going to happen. Take that away and what do you get? A boring mess is what.


Art 3/10:

This had a very cheap look to it like you could feel the lack of a budget. There were times where I could count the number of frames in a scene. On top of that, I didn't really like the general art style but that's just personal preference. The absolute worst is the awful censoring. I'm a big fan of mosaics because I feel like they leave enough to the imagination where an injury might actually seem worse due to the little you can see. The creators of this apparently don't agree as they decided to just slap a black shadow on it and call it a day. In the later stages when people are getting ripped apart and loses their heads every 5 seconds, it gets really distracting and takes you out of the show.


Sound 3/10:

I skipped the OP and ED every episode because they were bland and uninteresting. In terms of the music used throughout the show, it was OK but didn't really add anything other than a nice distraction. The real failure here is the sound effects and voice acting. There were a lot of cheap sounding sounds and a few that wouldn't look out of place on a free sound site from 2006. A lot of the voice acting felt very cartoonish and fake and at times was just hilariously awful, particularly when our MC screams or cries. What's even worse is that those parts are supposed to be some of the most serious, emotional parts of the show but makes you react in the complete opposite way which really detracts from the moment. Nothing like watching one character weep over the death of another while you're laughing at the stupidity of it all.


Character 1/10:

By far the worst part about this entire show. Characters range from being unintelligent yet mildly endearing one-dimensional husks to unbearable, borderline mentally disabled one-dimensional husks. To start with our MC, he's everything I hate in a character. He's whiny, delusional, bland, generic, you name it. He runs around trying to do the cliche thing of "I must protect everyone" then proceeds to protect no one. His motivation for this is pretty weak too. The rest of the cast in both timelines are not as bad but by no means good. There are a few somewhat bearable characters, as mentioned before, but they're really just fodder as they're all good friends with the MC and he has to watch them die or have a mental breakdown and then cry about it for half an episode. I did mention this before but the most frustrating part is that EVERYONE is stupid. No exceptions. Pick any character throughout the show and they are guaranteed to do something incomprehensibly stupid at least once throughout their screen time. It starts off annoying and descends into genuinely painful and it's not a slow transition either.


Enjoyment 1/10:

This anime was not enjoyable at all. By the end, I couldn't even derive pleasure out of complaining about it. There were times were I felt like I should laugh at how awful this show is but didn't have the strength to do it. As far as I'm concerned, this show is devoid of enjoyment past maybe episode 6 (very generous estimate).


Overall 1/10:

The only reason I didn't drop this show like a sack of bricks down an elevator shaft is to write this review and warm people. Unless you are a masochist, and a big one at that, or hate yourself or don't mind an endless barrage of plot holes, annoying characters, and edge or maybe some combination of the three, stay far far away from this anime. I barely scratched the surface of the problems this train wreck has but I think I put together enough of a list to put at least someone off watching this abomination. You've been warned, stay away.

Alright. Ousama Game: The Animation, or King's Game.
A survival game genre show adapted from a manga of the same name, Ousama game revolves around the main character, Nobuaki Kanazawa, and his classmates as they're thrust into a confusing and terrifying game. The basic premise goes as such: the students receive a text from the "King," where they are given 24 hours to follow an order, and failure to do so results in punishment. End of premise. With this knowledge, I think it's reasonable to expect some interesting psychological play as the students try to figure out how to conquer the game, and an eagerness fromthe viewer to understand the nature and origin of the game itself. Sadly, the show falls flat in basically every way.


Just as a disclaimer, this show is an adaptation, meaning there is source material for it. I have not read the source material, nor plan to, and the rest of this will be conducted solely on the show's merits.


The Story:

To go into this without as few spoilers as possible for anyone who feels the need to watch this show for whatever reason, the story is boring. Linear. Uninteresting. Beyond the premise of the show, there's nothing about the story that is interesting. It's also confusing and jumbled. In 12 episodes, the viewer is taken through the story of not only one, but two classes involved with the King's Game: the main character's current class, and his class at the school he went to previously (unlucky guy, right?). The story of his old class is told through flashbacks, which unfortunately are not very distinguishable from the scenes in current time. This can be confusing and incoherent until the viewer figures out who is who, and in which story line they belong.


And I'll try to keep everything else further away from spoiler territory, but the punishments are just ridiculous. It's all just death. Death everywhere. And it's all senseless. There's no reason for it, just like there's no reason for anything in this show, and is probably my biggest gripe. Every punishment is death, except for two times. But those just ended up with death anyway. More about this in the Art section below.


On top of that, there is absolutely no payoff anywhere. There's generally one pretty good assumption that can be made with survival game genres: the game is won when there's only one person left. Of course this gets tossed to the wayside often, but with this understanding, you can basically watch this knowing that our main character is the only survivor of his first King's Game. Unfortunately it seems that he's learned nothing, as he continues to meet with failure, and any "clues" he picked up in his first Game don't really pan out to be worth anything. There is no usefulness that came from the first Game, and the trend continues with the current Game. By the end of it, nothing is accomplished and the viewer is left looking for any form of accomplishment, of which there is none.


The Characters:

This should sound familiar: boring, linear, uninteresting. Unfortunately, none of the characters are likable. Even our main character, the hero of the class, is just...uninteresting. These characters go through no development, and in some cases even devolve. Which, I guess, might be a reasonable thing to expect when people are dying for no reason everywhere. But even this is just faked, because early on in the show you get to see how all of the characters react to the situation. Some will randomly change their tune for a time to fit whatever you can call the narrative, but these are often abrupt and don't make sense at all.


The Art:

Boring, flat (new word), and uninteresting. Everything is dull and there's little depth to any of the art. Except, of course, when someone dies. It's like someone wrote down a bunch of needlessly violent and grotesque ways to die on a piece of paper, made copies, put them in a hat, and pulled them out one by one every time they killed someone, which is always. The animation on the deaths of the characters are sadly the most impressive moments on the show. But it's just so needlessly violent. Oh, and magic, by the way. Other than that, when they wanted to give a brief respite from the gruesomeness, they were able to create some decent backgrounds and set pieces, but I don't particularly find that difficult to do when the rest of the show is steeped in dullness and death.


The Sound:

Average. Of course, when someone dies they went all out. But other than that, nothing of note. The soundtrack is not memorable, nor are the opening or ending songs and sequences of the show.


The Conclusion:

You can absolutely skip this show. Much like the characters, plot, deaths, etc., it's useless. There's nothing to be gained from this show unless you want to do a case study on how to graphically animate uselessly magic deaths. The character sufferings amount to nothing in a story that amounts to nothing. No payoff or any form of satisfaction at all. Really disappointing because the premise of the show actually sounded like it might harbor an interesting psychological survival game.


It didn't.

King's Game has an interesting premise. As a person who's really into the "killing game/play or die" type anime, I honestly loved it. 
Ok, first, I get that it isn't the most unique anime. The art isn't unique and we've seen similar anime before. But, the fact that the story isn't new doesn't make it a bad anime. It has its flaws but it's definitely not the worst thing I've watched.
The story was pretty good. After transferring schools, Nobuaki lives a relatively peaceful life...but soon gets involved in a second game of death. This anime makes it possible to have not readthe manga and still understand it. As a person who's read the manga, I wondered how they were going to explain the events of the first King's Game Nobuaki was involved in. The anime's use of flashbacks really helped show what happened in the manga. It wasn't complicated or tedious and it didn't feel like bad pacing at all. Also, in my opinion, they made an already good scene in the manga even better in the anime. And the anime's ending was better than the one given in the manga...


Anyway, the art's not bad but I do admit that the characters make somewhat weird faces when they're terrified. Then again, that may have been intentional since they're, you know, terrified. The animation is this anime's biggest problem. It's a bit weird at times, especially when they show a character's face from afar. 


The characters don't have the most complex personalities. You understand them most of the time but, if you get really into the anime, you just get mad at the ones who end up doing unreasonable or bad things. Nobuaki's a character you feel bad for and pity but you root for him because you want him to win after everything he's been through. Natsuko might have the most character development in this anime. She's nice to everyone and then...boom! Her personality does a total 180. But, trust me, there's a reason for her change in personality. As for the other characters, their personalities either correspond to a trope but add on to it or they just kinda lack in that area. 


Now, I absolutely love the music. The opening is one of the best ones for this anime season. The ending song is also really good. The dramatic music is timed well so there's no problems with the sounds at all.

Ousama Game The Animation is what happens when an idiot ball knocks down every character like bowling pins and scores a strike on the audience's intelligence.
The story is very poor. There are two primary stories, a story set in the past and one set in the present. The outcome of the past story is already apparent, so it's impossible to get into and the present day story isn't much better. Both follow the orders of the Ousama game, these orders usually ranging from remarkable simple only to be fumbled by character stupidity or so vague they're merely an excuse to butcher some more characters. There'svery little attempt to immerse you in the world of the show as there seems to be nothing outside of the cast going on and it makes everything feel particularly empty and uninteresting. There are also vast leaps in logic that are incredibly difficult to suspend disbelief for, even for a killing game. You simply have to put more effort into world building for these kinds of scenarios. Most of the actual horror comes in the show's theme of pointless cruelty, which would be an alright set up were it not for the characters themselves. Speaking of which...


The characters are not good. In an anime where anyone could die at any time, you really need developed and interesting characters so it can hurt all the more when the show kills them off or they're put in peril. There are flashes of this, but usually only in characters who are about to be killed off or don't last very long. There's usually 3 primary characters the show builds on and develops at all and the rest of the cast tends to be fodder for the orders. Most characters also seem to have a remarkably flexible morality, as in one scene they can be scared teenagers trying to survive and in the next they are turning on one another and becoming psychopathic murdering rapists. And that's not hyperbole, there's multiple examples in the show of characters doing a 180. The protagonist is a particular point of contention, he seems more fitting for a shonen protagonist as despite his experiences, he is insistent upon hope and that everyone can survive when he knows for a fact that is impossible. There's no real attempt to explore this either, a shonen protagonist trapped in an unwinnable situation has more potential than this show gave it.


The sound is... alright. Nothing particularly great or bad. The music was good for raising suspense and suited the atmosphere, the voice acting was generally decent but nothing standout. It's so unremarkable it's not worth watching the show for.


The art ranges from decent to bad. A lot of the gore and the actual horrific moments tend to be blurred out or are so horrific they're hard to take seriously and come across as something more out of the Evil Dead than a horror show wanting to be taken seriously. Most of the character designs are very forgettable, it has the 'main character design' syndrome where the only characters that matter get slightly effort driven designs whilst everyone else is stuck with your usual classroom fodder look. 


Enjoyment for this show is rock bottom. I didn't enjoy it as a horror anime, as a story or as a piece of animated media. Honestly the only enjoyment you can get out of Ousama game is watching it for the 'so bad it's good' quality. But that's only present in a couple of episodes and you'll probably find yourself shouting at the screen rather than laughing at the ridiculous scenarios. 


This is not a good show. This is not a good horror anime. Do not watch it unless you simply desire to see a train wreck in motion. This Ousama Game was over before it even started.

The survival game genre in anime has created some nice gems over time, like Death Parade and Future Diary. However now I have arrived at Kings Game, which has no idea how a goddamn survival game works.
Story (5/10)
The story concentrates on a group of classmates, who have each been given an order by the King. If they don't complete the order within 24 hours they will be punished.
That's pretty much the gist of the story, however this anime has no idea how to tell a story properly. Our MC Nobuaki Kanazawa is a new transfer student and tries to warn his current classabout the Kings game, but their having none of that and have a big dispute in the middle of a park at night. This lasts for almost 3 goddamn episodes, putting that aside though most of the first half concentrates on what happened at the previous school Nobu was at. 

This irritated me, because it cut time from the present events that were happening just so the anime can explain what happened in the previous Kings Game, this felt really unnecessary, because we already had a line up of characters ready to go and now the anime wants us to feel bad for some other characters who had already been killed by the game. What makes it even more annoying is that these characters were more appealing and interesting compared to the present group, who had only one or two somewhat tolerable characters (if you discount Nobu).

So after the flashback episodes, the second half finally concentrates on the current group that we began with and I will admit the story did pick up a little as the final episodes approached and the numbers of classmates continued to dwindle.

But after fighting against the impossible, the remaining characters at the end figure out that the only way to finish the game is to actually kill yourself and guess what, everybody actually dies. Although it was done in a pretty surprising way, which is then completely killed by the after credit scene trying to fool us into thinking a sequel could be possible.


Characters (3/10)


The most annoying and boring part of this show was it's characters, I'm only gonna mention the interesting ones because practically everyone were either assholes or cannon fodder for the king to kill.


Nobu is the MC and the only character you really feel for. Being the only survivor of the previous Kings Game he desperately tries during both games to save everyone and since everyone keeps dying from every angle, you feel sorry for the amount of effort this guy puts in to try and save his friends, hell even the new class treated him like sh*t at first and he still tried to save them. It's even more sad what happens to him in the end.

Natsuko Honda is the sister of Nobu's previous girlfriend Chiemi. At first she seems like that cute girl, whose always helpful and everyone likes her which really annoyed me from the get go. However she is also like Nobu, a previous survivor of a Kings Game and is actually a complete and total Bit*h, this made her character 100x more interesting. Her levels of evil were so high that no matter how much you hate her, you have to respect the evilness within her. Luckily she gets what she deserves in the end.

Ria Iwamura is a character from Nobu's first game. Compared to everyone else playing the game, she was actually trying to figure a way out of it and despite her cold, isolated nature she was actually pretty badass and was the only other person aside from Nobu that you wanted to stick up for. Hell even the way she died was badass compared to everyone else.

Riona Matsumoto is sorta like Ria when it came to playing the game, she tried to figure out a way to end the game, but she felt like a bit of a hindrance and never really made things easy for Nobu, plus she and Nobu do develop feelings for each other which also felt kinda forced. Although I do feel pretty sorry for the girl as she ends up seeing her new love die right in front of her and ends up killing herself to stop the game ever happening again.

All the other characters were like I said either assholes or just cannon fodder for the King to kill, so don't bother forming attachments to any of the other characters, except the ones I said.


Art (5/10)


Now these types of anime tend to have pretty gory stuff and this anime is no different, however when it came to the artstyle of the deaths themselves they felt bland and pretty overexaggerated really. The looks on the characters faces whenever they were or were about to die looked really goofy, almost to the point where it was  as hilarious as Kakegurui's facial expressions and they were something else.

The designs of the characters also looked bland as hell, I mean they looked like they were stolen from a bunch of different anime's and slightly changed. 


Sound (5/10)


I will give credit to the OP, the music was alright and didn't make me skip it everytime I saw it, although the OP's animation sequence was pretty poor and looked like the bare minimal was put into it. The same can be said for ED, which wasn't as enjoyable to watch or listen too.

The soundtrack wasn't really memorable at all and seemed like the kinda stuff you'd usually experience in these kind of anime's.


Extras:


Now as a Horror this sucked pretty much, the deaths seemed bland and didn't have a lot of variety, it was mainly people being hung or being dismembered which is the usual way people are killed in these types of horrors. Although I will admit there are a couple of deaths that were pretty gruesome like some of the characters were killed with a Chainsaw which did make the current scene a lot more intense. I also liked the episode where the remaining characters had to form a circle and had to choose whether to break their fingers or not, this scene was pretty tense and the way it turned out was a lot more brutal than I was expecting.

Usually there is always an element of mystery in survival games, which is usually the key to surviving it. However this anime completely butchers it's mystery element and really pissed me off, at first the characters suspect it's actually one of them pulling a prank until it got way out of hand with most of them dead. Then they try to go to the location of where it all started, turns out the King is actually a parasitic virus within the internet that only affects certain people. This was ridiculous and completely stupid, making it look like it had copied When They Cry's plot twist and just made it more technical, which was absolutely bullsh*t.


Enjoyment (5/10)


This anime annoyed me, but also entertained me at the same time. Some parts had their ups while others had their downs. 


Overall (5/10)


Overall this is a pretty mixed bag of annoyance and thrill, it starts off pretty damn annoying, but if you stick it out till the end you might some enjoyable moments. Until you watch the ending where literally everything was for nothing.

I think the reviews here that are mostly 1-2/10 are certainly on to something. This pathetic piece of work is disappointing and I be surprised to find someone who thinks its at least good from an objective point of view; the concept of a survival game will always demand high expectations from viewers. 
To be honest, I'm not one to judge harshly on an anime, but at the very least there is a story line I can follow, characters whose actions I can judge logically, sound that isn't disturbing enough for me to want to turn it off, and visuals that are still properly animatedalbeit not the best. So I think its fair to say that each of those factors in Ousama Game deserve approximately a 4 for decency. 


Even with such mediocre scores, I managed to enjoy Ousama Game to the end by simply changing my thinking. While I don't think its a must-watch, its still possible to enjoy for some who are willing to change their mindset and try not to over-analyse too much. 


Story

The story follows the MC (whose name I forgot, I'm writing this review weeks after finishing it actually), who won a previous King's Game and lost all of his former classmates and inevitably enters a new game with his new classmates. All while referring back to the former game when necessary and revealing all the important aspects of the previous games which will benefit the current one: which, to be honest, I thought they structured quite well. 


The King's Game has rules, like all survival games and breaking such rules leads to death. Warning: The King's Game isn't designed to be won, which is obvious right at the start. People are forced to undertake almost or directly impossible and unfair orders. Most of which are sexual or gory which is what drops most of the plot. Oh, not to mention that the rules are ambiguous to confuse the characters on purpose.


Overall, its pretty much a fun way to see how the characters react in such a situation. Obviously there is some progress, but with the pace it goes to quickly kill off everyone there's hardly any room for detective stuff. So yeah, the focus is mainly based on this mild horror and tragedy of these characters that they execute. 


There's nothing to say about the art and sound because its not really important. (And also I don't remember, but the fact that its not bad enough for me to remember means something right?) So I'm gonna head straight to...

Character

OK So I'm gonna say straight off the bat that the current classmates were not the right cast for the situation at hand. While they manage to make logical attempts to discover the true antagonist, but fail to change the direction of the plot.

While there is a fair share of psychotic and insane characters driven by fear of death, there are very few characters with actual common sense within these group of idiots that I actually like, believe it or not. 


Basically they either go insane, go along with the game and hope for the best, and there are a select few that don't mind dying and would rather do so than kill.


Overall

I managed to finish all 12 episodes without dropping it for a reason. Its not scary, thrilling, hardly a mystery and barely makes it as a comedy series (because of how bad it is); though I can somewhat indulge into the pity and helplessness of the characters current conditions. Introducing: Flashback; The Animation!
Well I just finished watching "Ousama Game, The Animation". I don't really know how I feel now that it's over, Just when you think the show can't get any more stupid, it somehow manages to do just that. 
There are so many unanswered questions, What exactly is the King's game? Who is the king? Why was this show made? Why am I watching it? And why is there a second season coming out??
The show was structured very poorly. As I previously touched on, Flashbacks are a big part of this show, and i'm talking about 60% of the first half of theseries takes place in a flashback. They obviously had a lot of things that they wanted to cover, so why they didn't focus on the MC's first King's game only is beyond me, especially as there's going to be a season 2. 


The actual plot itself isn't awful, I like the idea of it, however I feel it was poorly done in practice. It really did feel like an edgy Mirai Nikki clone more times than it should have.



The art was very dull to look at and overall looked about 10 years older than it is, there were some truly awful looking effects and some glaring inaccuracies. For example. a character trips on a tree root as she is running forward, then suddenly there is a cliff edge and she falls down it, facing backwards...


The sound was nothing special either. The only thing of note is the Opening theme, which I did enjoy. Everything else was just forgettable, not terrible, but nothing to write home about either. 


And now for my biggest problem with this show; the characters. Never have I watched a show where I've thought that most, if not all the characters were complete morons. but Ousama game changed that. 


We have our male lead, Nobuaki, he's about as cookie cutter as you can get, and he only seems to have two characteristics, he's either trying to save everybody, or he's crying, because he can't save everybody. The only character I really liked was the main female Antagonist, but I even began to find her insufferable as the episodes went on. 


This next paragraph contains some minor spoilers, so skip if you want to stay unspoiled: 


My issue with the characters, and by extension, the writing, is never more evident than in one particular scene. A friend of Nobuaki has been sentenced to death via suicide by midnight. so Nobuaki and a friend decide to stay with him all night to make sure he doesn't kill himself. The scene was actually quite good at first, with them playing music together and having a good time, It gets to midnight, and they're all relieved that he's still alive. He then basically goes "right i'm off to get a drink" and the others are perfectly fine with this, which already had me questioning the writing. and sure enough, Nobuaki's phone was 5 minutes off, it's not midnight yet! sure enough, the character in question was shortly found hanging. 


It's scenes like this which make the show laughable. things seem to happen only because they're necessary to the plot, with no rhyme or reason. 


I have so many questions about the show that weren't answered in the first season of this show. and I have to ask myself, do I care enough to watch season 2 whenever that may start airing? 


The answer is yes, surprisingly, I by no means thought that the show was good, but for some reason I couldn't bring myself to drop it, even after 6 episodes of flashbacks and stupidity. I often found myself laughing at the show for the wrong reasons, and I was genuinely curious to see if it could get any more ridiculous as the show progressed. And for that, I have to give it a couple of points.



I give Ousama game; the Animation a 3/10. Watch this show if you're looking for something to laugh at, or if you really, really like survival anime and haven't seen this yet. 


Alternatively, you can do what I'm about to go and do, and watch Mirai Nikki Instead.

Man, I had to recover my account just to write this review, because I can't believe the collective hate this anime is getting.  I can only imagine the primary people writing reviews for this anime must be the same personality types that grew up on Disney fairy tales and cotton candy dreams where, "The hero rides off into the sunset with the princess," or "You will always triumph in the end as long as you believe in the power of love and justice," and "Tears are phoenix downs," or someother bullcrap like that.  I truly find it unbelievable people can suspend their disbelief for a man who exercises like a regular human yet can destroy planet-busting aliens in a single punch, yet trash talk anime like this and School Days because they do something other than their Walgreens-perfect expectations predict.


Let Uncle Mist87 teach you a lesson, kiddies, and welcome you to the world of horror, where nightmares and phantasms rule, the hero doesn't ride off into the sunset, things go downhill quicker than a rock shot from a rocket launcher down a mountain, and your cotton candy is nothing but an additive to soothe your junkie craving so the sugar industry can keep making mountains of dough.  For I wasn't a kid who grew up on Disney dreams, but Goosebumps nightmares, and for that I can appreciate this murder-fest in all its horrific glory. Story:  8


The story itself isn't that original:  A transfer who wants nothing to do with anyone arrives at another school, then he gets a text from "the King" telling him he has to do something with another student or get punished.  Other students also soon get texted, and soon learn not following the King's orders within 24 hours or breaking his rules equals death.  The concept seems simple enough, but what happens when an order requires you to betray someone you care about, or to choose which of your classmates will die?  This added great psychological depth to the story, especially when seeing the cast's sanity degrade based on the choices they have to make.  


The pacing of King's Game is probably the greatest thing I appreciated about the story.  In a sense, this 12 episode anime fit two stories in one, for as the new class is discovering what to do during their first King's Game, the story flashbacks into the events of another King's Game, making the action never let up even when things in the current game are slowly progressing.  This presented an interesting answer to pacing I've never seen before (We can't all be perfectly paced like Code Geass or break everything into small "What Ifs" like Higurashi, now can we?), and something that would solve pacing issues in other anime also.  It's the reverse of what you usually see, where flashbacks are used to slow down the action to give the audience a breather.  


Art 7:


I'm no art aficionado, so all I can say is the art looked decent to me.  It wasn't as smooth as it should have been most times, but it failed to diminish my enjoyment of the series.  If I was to give a reason why I didn't rank the art higher, it would be the lack of intricate details in the blood and gore when the characters die their horrible, horrible deaths when losing in the King's Game.  For so many characters dying such miserable deaths, you'd think they'd put more detail in the gore.  


Sound 9:


I had no issue with sound quality.  The music got creepy when needed, and could play to the emotion of character deaths when necessary (when a character you cared about died).  I'm also a huge rock fan, so the opening soundtrack along with the visuals got me amped, and is something rare in this era of classical, operatic music and rap beats.  I seriously would play the opening two to three times before I watched each episode. 


Character 6:


Naturally, when you have an anime with such a large cast yet only 12 episodes to tell their tale, characterization is going to be the most lacking element.  Most of the cast are nothing more than fodder for the King's Game, while we're given peeks into the backstories of the more interesting characters, but not much else.  And, of course, as a once top-charting rapper once said, "Where are de parents at?!"  I mean, is it implied the cast lives in a boarding school, or do the parents not care everyone in their son/daughter's class is dropping like flies after a Raid bombing? 24 episodes would have fit the large cast better, and I'm hoping other anime will learn this lesson in the future:  If you have a lot of frickin characters, go big or go home.  


Enjoyment 9... Overall 7

Quickly, think about some good horror anime! The first ones that come to your mind are probably Corpse Party, Another or Higurashi. This anime had clearly the opportunity to be on the same level as the above ones. Did Ousama Game manage to do it?  
No, it definitely didn't. Was it at least a decent watch? No, not even that. But let's give it a closer look what made this anime fail so miserably. 
Story: An entire high school class of 32 people receive a message on their cellphones from a person known only as the "King." The messages contain orders that the studentsmust obey, or they get the punishment of death. With their lives on the line, the students soon find out that the orders are getting more and more extreme as time goes on. But one student, Nobuaki Kanazawa, is determined to put a stop to the murderous King's Game, once and for all. That's the setup for this show, but beyond that, there is almost no story, and for sure none that makes sense. Unrealistic and stupid decisions are the only thing the characters are capable of doing. Really predictable and simple, the story isn't able to surprise the viewer in any good manner.


Characters: This series has basically two important characters throughout it's run. Everybody else gets built up for 2-3 episodes and then blindly thrown away. The rest of the cast are there just for gruesome kills and a high body count. Nobuaki is the MC who can just cry and say he will change anything. Nevertheless, he is the hope of a lot of the students. Natsuko Honda is the main antagonist and pretty much the other side of Nobuaki, reflecting his hope as a symbol of despair. Those two have a common secret that is obviously the only reason exactly those two are important and to keep focus on, and no one else. We still have some (already dead) side characters that only play a role in the uninteresting mind of Nobuaki.


Animation and Sound: The animation and art was atrocious. This is the era of digital anime. Everything is created by computers nowadays. Pen and paper have been replaced with  Adobe Illustrator/Photoshop and yet… they still made a show that could have passed as an extremely low budget show in the 90s. Some of the scenes were animated so poorly, you could easily harken back to the days where you could tell that a single animation cell was being dragged across the lens of a camera. Some scenes even looked like they were missing a few key frames as everything was even more jittery than normal.The sound is in no way good either, more like an action anime than horror. It felt like the studio just wanted to go with the "mainstream", which clearly was the wrong step here. At least, some of the soundtracks are by themself good enough to be entertaining.


Enjoyment: Here, I really have to give it at least some credit. Story and characters don't do it, we're rather "entertained" by this shows weaknesses. Sometimes, you even laugh about how bad the anime is, but then you realise they tried to make it good. The games are creative and entertaining too, which is at least a bit diversified. The deaths are gruesome, over the top and clearly stupid. And that's what makes you love those scenes soooo much. At one point, a guys head is exploded. At another point, a girl talks over 2 minutes calmly while being burned to death by flames. It is unrealistic, yes, but that's made clear from the very beginning. And that's again even funny. Still, bad story and even worse characters drag the enjoyment down, but sometimes being entertained by how bad this anime is is entertaining as well.



Overall: Don't watch it. That is my final statement. I could've talked a lot more about the bad things in this anime, but have said pretty much everything good. If you aren't a hardcore horror fan or just want to watch laughable stupid episodes, skip this anime. And if you want to watch a good horror anime, get the examples I mentioned at the beginning of this text.

If you liked Michael Grant’s Gone series, or thought, ‘hmm, I really like the premise of a bunch of kids being trapped in an inevitably hopeless situation where they end up dying gruesome deaths for utterly terrible reasons’, then King’s Game is for you. 
I think I picked it up for the same reason I picked up School Days, or the same reason people click on a spoiler when they know they shouldn’t: curiosity. I wanted to know why this series was so infamous, especially when the synopsis sounded interesting. I wanted to know what all the fuss was about.
I don’t know why I foundthis anime entertaining – maybe it’s because I didn’t take it seriously from the get go and so just enjoyed it as a mindless despair/gorefest. Similar to how people ‘enjoy’ something like Higurashi or Another. 


The characters were so-so, some of them could have done with more development but when they were developed they were done so decently enough. The art was fine most of the time, although there were points where the animation quality dropped greatly. Music was good. And as for the seiyuus – I think they were great. They actually managed to sound like they were in pain when they were meant to be in pain (at least the majority of them did). There was some fanservice, but not nearly as bad as I expected based on a couple of the reviews I’d read. Apart from the very first scene and another scene about halfway through the series, there was really nothing worth mentioning. And even those scenes weren’t that terrible.


The torture was another story. Like I said, it’s a gorefest. But gory in an immature way. Worse than Elfen Lied or Akame ga Kill!, but not by much. Besides most of the scenes were done in such a ridiculous way it was hard to take them seriously. 


Let me be clear, the only (or at least the main) reason that I’m giving it a bad score (in my rating system, anything under 6 is bad) is because the plot holes were so gaping huge they were impossible to ignore. This was objectively a terrible anime in terms of plot – it literally makes no sense if you think about it for more than a second or two. I had absolutely no idea what was going on at the end. But I still found it okay on the whole.


It was actually very thought-provoking, in a way – it made me wonder what I would do if I was in a similar position. One where I was completely at the mercy of a situation I couldn’t understand, having no idea what would happen next except that it would be inescapable, and painful no matter the outcome. Not to mention that the longer I survived, the more despairing I would be when I inevitably came to die. 


I ended up thinking the characters behaved quite realistically. I mean, in their situation, there were really only 3 choices:

•	Suffer a total mental breakdown and either commit suicide or lose all sense of reality. Maybe try to take everyone else with you for good measure.

•	Try to keep yourself from going over the brink by desperately clinging onto some form of hope - reassuring everyone else helps too. 

•	Completely lock off your emotions and become a robot – regard the entire situation dispassionately and logically try to find a way out. It doesn’t matter if no one but you survives.


I’m actually not sure which one of these I would be…interesting to think about, if a little gloomy.


So, those are my impressions. The abysmal plotline prevented me from giving it anything higher than a 5, but there were interesting parts, and, overall, I didn’t dislike it. So, if you like gore, a big cast of characters, and don’t mind a terrible storyline, you can try giving it a go. You’ll be able to tell what it’s like after the first 3 episodes anyway; it doesn’t progress much. XD

A perfect example of an attempt at horror gone wrong. Ousama Game: The Animation is in short, a train wreck and easily the worst anime to premiere this season. 
In all 12 of its episodes, there is very little to be said about what the show accomplishes. If anything, the more you watch, the more you will hate every passing moment. 
The anime starts out somewhat promising and quite typical with regards to most horror anime. There is a lot of disbelief and confusion at the beginning, typical of anyone that receives random text messages from an unknown sender. This quickly turns into madness andchaos ensues as people begin to die suddenly. 


The anime does a bad job of making an interesting, cohesive story that can capture your attention for 12 episodes. The anime relies heavily on flashbacks, and we only ever get them from the main Nobuaki Kanazawa, who happened to survive the last game that he played. This the only character they give so much attention to during the run of the show and yet in attempts to frame him as the potential hero, albeit heavily damaged, and yet while he may have redeeming qualities, these flashbacks just take up space rather than helping propel the current story forward. There is a lot more that could have been done with the present story and depth that could have been built that was lost in trying to ground the story in events that have already come to pass. 


My other gripe with the story is that it just feels weak in general. There is an attempt to put an end to it, as the characters try to find the origins of the game and “solve the puzzle” so they no longer have to play, but like the show, their efforts are pointless in that there is no bigger picture to solve. We never get an understanding of where the game really comes from, who is running this game, or if there is a way of winning that is truly satisfying. Whether the point was to illustrate a winning game of a game you are meant to lose is not the issue, the issue arises from the fact that neither matters and it seeks to show us pointless and ridiculous deaths while the characters act just as ridiculously. 


The worst part of the show is without a doubt all of the characters we are presented with. This has to be the shallowest, most naive, unconvincing characters I have seen in a while. They see the events unrolling around them and yet are still unwilling to accept that this “game” they are a part of is real. They run around like chickens without heads and their motivations and actions are all meaningless and nonsensical beyond the simple desire to survive. We get around 30 or so characters throughout the 12 episodes, many of which die, but many also who the show focuses on and yet is unable to develop them beyond the worst typical traits present in a high school drama or horror film.

Nobuaki Kanazawa has just transferred school but he tries desperately to keep his distance from everyone despite how friendly they were. He was the only survivor of something known as the "King's Game" where if someone didn't follow orders, they would die a horrible death instantly. Naturally when all his new classmates started receiving these orders on their phones they didn't believe him... That is until, chaos broke out and a large number of them died the first night. Now it's a game of seeing how far each of them will go for survival.
So the story is loosely based around the "ou-sama" game in Japanwhich is usually pulling straws to see who has the longest one. Then they can tell someone in the game to do whatever they must. Kind of like the truth or dare game. Show itself is based on a mix of the Manga's first series and the first title in the second series subtitled "終極 [The Finale]".


The first half of this show is mostly flashbacks of Nobuaki's past experience of the King's Game and it's mostly filled with non-stop gorey, gruesome deaths and little plot or character development. It's kind of like watching everyone getting filled with angst as they learn of each other dying and a lot of times, you'll be thinking, "Wha...?" The dares are gruesome and a lot of them is forcing the female students to have sex or some other exploitive situation. It's nothing explicit visually and I guess they at least show a condom being used.


After most of the class has disappeared, that the show kind of gets better as the story focuses more on the remaining few survivors of the present class so you start to sympathise with the characters a bit more. Some people have compared this horror show to Another but, I think Another was better because its mystery side was kept throughout the show instead of focusing on slaughtering or making characters suffer episode after episode.


If you're into sadistic shows and enjoy watching gorey, gruesome deaths or people suffering then you might enjoy this. Otherwise, I'd suggest watching Another instead if you want a better horror mystery show.
